Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Santoro proposes to study special metrics on manifolds. This research project splits into four parts:the construction of complete Ricci-flat Kaehler metrics with special asymptotic behavior, the explicit construction of examples of anti-self dual metrics on 4-manifolds, the existence of Yang-Mills energy minimizers for Calabi-Yau manifolds, and the existence of complete, constant mean curvature hypersurfaces in Hyperbolic Space with prescribed behavior at infinity.

It is hard to overestimate the role played by Calabi-Yau Spaces and Yang-Mills Theory in Differential Geometry and Physics. Calabi-Yau manifolds, essentially shapes that satisfy the requirement of space for the six "unseen" spatial dimensions of the present model of Universe, are a key object of research in superstring theory. The problems investigated in this project are among the most natural in their context and possess several interesting additional applications in neighboring areas of Mathematics, such as Complex Geometry
and Topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: 

During the award period, the PI wrote 5 articles, 3 of which have been published, one is awaiting publication, and one has been submitted for publication. Here are the bibliographic data:

- Fibrations of genus 2 on Complex Surfaces (joint with J. Rebelo). Results in Mathematics (6 July 2011), pp. 1-35.

- Holonomy Groups in Riemannian Geometry (joint with A. Clarke). Publicacoes Matematicas do IMPA [IMPA Mathematical Publications], 2012. 126pp. ISBN: 978-85-244-03466-0.

- Existence of Kahler Ricci-flat metrics on crepant resolutions, Commun. Contemp. Math. 16 (2014), no. 3, 1450003.

- Equivariant deformations of Hamiltonian stationary Lagrangian submanifolds (joint with R. Bettiol and P. Piccione), to appear in Mat. Contemp.

- Bifurcation of Periodic Solutions to the Singular Yamabe Problem on Spheres. (joint with R. Bettiol and P. Piccione), submitted for publication. Preprint  arXiv:1401.7071.

Intellectual Merit:

The project had the intellectual merit of studying problems in complex and symplectic geometry, some of which have its roots in classical problems in theoretical physics, using new techniques that have specifically designed for the problems in question. In particular, one of the completed subprojects (Existence of Ricci-flat metrics on crepant resolutions) has been motivated by important questions in string theory, namely the structure of gravitational instantons, and their possible generalizations to higher dimensions.

Broader Impacts:

All the results obtained by PI are available online at ArXiv and at her webpage, including the two introductory books the PI has written for graduate students (one of which was produced during the current support. She has presented her work in 16 seminars/conferences. While supported by this grant, the PI has also been the co-organizer of three seminars at her home institution, and two conferences at the Graduate Center Also, the PI was a panelist on a post-play discussion of ”Truth Values”, by Gioia di Cari, about the role of women in mathematics.

Regarding the broader community, the PI participated as a judge of the New York Science Fair 2013, and has been involved, since 2011, with a program of math enrichment for 1st and 2nd graders at PS 278, a Title I school in Manhattan, that serves a community of considerable need. The last is a joint effort with Prof. Cleary, CCNY and Prof. St. John, Lehman College.

Concerning student advising, the PI has mentored 1 high school student, 3 undergraduates and 2 masters students during the current award.
